39477171.review:
I think you get the gist of it at the first video. 

All systems are working. The cockpit looks dauting at first. I thought the barrier to entry would be too high, but it really isn't. Every single system is simple and has a clear cut part to play in the whole. The complexity is what you make of it. If you decide to not push any operational limit and just go by the book, then it's just a matter of being meticulous.

If you ever wanted to fly a space ship from within an A-10 cockpit with a lot of switches then this is a game you should have in your library. How would you plan to solve Kerbal problems with flick switches from inside the cockpit?

The big part of this game is when you are so familiarized with the cockpit that you shift your gaze from the cockpit internals and use this baby to accomplish tasks in the outside world. 

The experience is so flexible that you eventually develop your individual style and habits as a pilot, but that's part of the rewarding experience. 

With all the "candy crush" style of space flight "sims" out there. It's good to have a nice and quiet option where the sense of accomplishment is mastery without a clickfest with split second timing.

38702615.review:
I'm not going to recommend buying this, and i'm not going to recommend that you dont. This sim falls into a very unique category where I believe, that at least for it's sale price of a usual 10$, offers a very interesting, unique, and immersive experience that nothing else really provides. 

That said, it's an experience, not a game. Unfortunately, I do not see Rogue System ever becoming a full fledged game. It's being worked on by a single guy who refuses basically all help, and I honestly believe the scope is far too large for the one man to handle. You can see the utterly massive gaps in between updates and dev communications. It doesnt spell good things for the future of Rogue System. 

If you find it on sale, and want to have a unique, immersive experience that you can mess with every so often and dont expect it to evolve much beyond that, then Rogue System is a pretty interesting buy. I dont regret the 10$ I spent, but I love space sims and this is like DCS and KSP had a baby. I hope it continues to grow.

I must say for a one-man team this game is pretty good. It's light in content but what's there is promising, just learning on how to control your ship will take you a couple of days. Yes there are tutorials that explain to you what to do to get it working but to really understand what's what you need to learn it yourself. The batteries will explode, fuel cells will be depleted, everything will turn off and you'll be sitting there in a dark ship floating in space wondering what went wrong only to try again and begin with the star-up procedure. Once you really figure out on how to do all that you need to learn about orbital mechanics and automatic pilot settings.
Imagine Kerbal Space Program without the map that shows your orbit, you only get numbers and icons. Once you mange to go to a moon or planet you have to learn to rendez-vous, after that you have to learn to dock. I haven't even reached those parts yet.
For people with a love for realism and sci-fi.

38602388.review:
Rogue System has a solid foundation for a great space sim, maybe the most realistic ever made. The mechanics and physics are sound, and even the propulsion systems are based on actual next-gen ideas. Theres more buttons and functions than I have room for on my whole flight sim rig, but the game content is wanting. 
As of right now, its total sandbox, as in make up your own mission and finish it out. The dev says more is coming soon, and I can emphasize with him as its still a one man effort. Lately he has been posting more updates, which makes me more confident this sim will come to fruition. 
If he can manage a well balanced career, with goals and commerce and NPC ships and bases, this could be the space game to contend with KSP for my favorite. The basics are there, and very well fleshed out in terms of the ship and its systems. Now we just need something to do with it. 
Support this game and its developer, we might really have something special here.

37601181.review:
There is a particular segment of the gaming community whose deepest love is for hard-core simulations.  These simulations are like a blend of puzzle-game and action game, where you get as much satisfaction from learning how to use the simulated systems as from achieving goals within the game.  There is an element of education, as well, because you know that what you are learning is solidly based on how things work (or might work) in the real world, without any sugar-coating or compromises for "accessibility".  There is no "levelling up" or unlocking of bonuses in games like this - the only way to improve is for you to learn and get better!

Rouge System is a stunning one-man effort that even in early-access sits squarely at the pinnacle of its class, for space-flight simulations.
